Federated Learning With Energy Harvesting Devices: An MDP Framework

Kai Zhangâ€  and Xuanyu Caoâ€  (IEEE Senior Member)
â€ Department of Electronic and Computer Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) requires edge devices to perform local training and exchange information with a parameter server, leading to substantial energy consumption. A critical challenge in practical FL systems is the rapid energy depletion of battery-limited edge devices, which curtails their operational lifespan and affects the learning performance. To address this issue, we apply energy harvesting technique in FL systems to extract ambient energy for continuously powering edge devices. We first establish the convergence bound for the wireless FL system with energy harvesting devices, illustrating that the convergence is impacted by partial device participation and packet drops, both of which depend on the energy supply. To accelerate the convergence, we formulate a joint device scheduling and power control problem and model it as a Markov decision process (MDP). By solving this MDP, we derive the optimal transmission policy and demonstrate that it possesses a monotone structure with respect to the battery and channel states. To overcome the curse of dimensionality caused by the exponential complexity of computing the optimal policy, we propose a low-complexity algorithm, which is asymptotically optimal as the number of devices increases. Furthermore, for unknown channels and harvested energy statistics, we develop a structure-enhanced deep reinforcement learning algorithm that leverages the monotone structure of the optimal policy to improve the training performance. Finally, extensive numerical experiments on real-world datasets are presented to validate the theoretical results and corroborate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, energy harvesting, Markov decision process, monotone structure, the curse of dimensionality, deep reinforcement learning.

I Introduction

Machine learning is a cornerstone technology driving artificial intelligence (AI) in diverse fields, such as autonomous driving [1] and the Internet of Things [2]. Traditional centralized machine learning requires the aggregation and processing of distributed data on a central server, which leads to increased data traffic and raises concerns about data privacy and security. To address these issues, federated learning (FL) has emerged as a novel distributed machine learning paradigm that enables collaborative model training without uploading raw data to a central server[3]. In FL, edge devices (e.g., mobile phones and sensors) conduct local training on their respective datasets and subsequently exchange information (e.g., model parameters or gradients) with a parameter server. Due to its distinctive architecture, FL can alleviate the computation and communication burdens and preserve the data privacy of involved edge devices [4, 5].

In practical scenarios, the performance of FL is severely affected by radio resources, such as transmission power and bandwidth. The limited radio resources among participating edge devices hinder data transmission and increase communication latency, degrading the learning performance. To tackle these issues, numerous papers have investigated communication resource management for wireless FL systems. In [6], the authors investigated a joint radio resource allocation and user selection problem for wireless FL, aiming to minimize the training loss under delay and energy consumption constraints. A similar resource allocation problem of achieving the optimal tradeoff between convergence speed and power consumption for wireless FL was studied in [7]. In [8], the authors developed a joint computation and transmission scheme for wireless FL under a more challenging setting with heterogeneous data. While the aforementioned studies explored static resource allocation according to the statistical properties of wireless channels, other research focused on the dynamic allocation of communication resources. The authors of [9] proposed a dynamic power control policy based on instant channel state information (CSI) to speed up the convergence of over-the-air FL. Similarly, a dynamic device scheduling and power control scheme for over-the-air FL was developed in [10]. Bandwidth allocation for wireless FL has also been studied extensively. In [11], the authors investigated a joint device selection and bandwidth allocation problem for wireless FL, devising an online algorithm to maximize the number of participating devices in each round. A similar problem incorporating latency constraints was studied in [12]. Additionally, the authors of [13] studied a joint power and bandwidth allocation problem to simultaneously minimize the power consumption, computation cost, and time cost of wireless FL systems.

Despite the extensive research, all the aforementioned studies have either considered finite energy supply for edge devices or completely neglected the energy limitations. However, merely utilizing the finite energy stored in the batteries of edge devices will lead to a reduced operational lifespan. Once the battery is depleted, edge devices cannot contribute to the training process of FL, which degrades the learning performance. Additionally, frequent battery replacements and recharges are impractical, especially for devices deployed in remote or inaccessible environments. To address this issue, energy harvesting (EH) FL has emerged as a promising solution. This technique collects ambient energy (e.g., solar, wind or thermoelectric energy) to continuously power edge devices, thereby extending their operational lifetime and improving the learning performance. Furthermore, EH FL uses clean and renewable energy sources, making it more environmentally friendly compared to conventional FL with battery-powered edge devices. Several recent studies have investigated EH FL. In [14], a client scheduling algorithm was introduced to accelerate the convergence of FL over EH-enabled wireless networks. A joint device selection and resource allocation problem was investigated in [15] to reduce training latency and improve the data utility of EH FL. The authors of [16] extended this problem to a more sophisticated system, where the server employs massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) to serve clients. Exploiting the over-the-air computation, the authors of [17] proposed a bandwidth-efficient scheme for joint client selection and energy management in EH FL. In [18], a joint client selection and bandwidth allocation scheme was designed for FL with EH devices, aiming to minimize the ages of local models and the latency of global iterations. To accelerate the convergence of EH FL, the authors of [19] formulated a joint transceiver design and device scheduling problem and developed a Lyapunov-based online optimization algorithm to solve it.

The prior works [14, 15, 16, 17, 18] on EH FL concentrate on designing transmission strategies for one typical time slot. However, the overall performance of FL is affected by the cumulative model aggregation errors over the entire training period, necessitating careful utilization of harvested energy from a long-term perspective. We note that [19] is an early attempt to optimize the long-term efficiency of EH FL. However, its online optimization algorithm fails to exploit the statistical knowledge of system dynamics, e.g., the distributions of the channel gains and the amount of harvested energy, resulting in suboptimal learning performance. Thus, in this paper, we are motivated to develop a Markov decision process (MDP) framework for designing the optimal transmission policy of EH FL. The proposed MDP framework utilizes the statistical knowledge of channels and harvested energy to address their inherent stochastic nature, thereby enabling efficient utilization of harvested energy and enhanced learning performance. The main contributions are summarized as follows.

1) We characterize the convergence bound of the wireless FL system with EH devices, demonstrating the impacts of partial device participation and packet drops, both of which further depend on the energy supply. Based on the convergence bound, we formulate a joint device scheduling and power control problem to minimize the optimality gap between the expected and optimal global loss.

2) We propose an MDP framework for the formulated optimality gap minimization problem and compute the optimal transmission policy. We prove that the optimal policy exhibits a monotone structure with respect to the battery and channel states. Moreover, to overcome the curse of dimensionality caused by the exponential complexity of computing the optimal policy, we propose a low-complexity algorithm that is asymptotically optimal as the number of devices increases.

3) For a more general scenario with unknown channels and harvested energy statistics, we develop a structure-enhanced deep reinforcement learning (SE-DRL) algorithm that leverages the monotone structure of the optimal policy to improve the training performance.

4) We validate the theoretical results and evaluate the performance of the proposed algorithms on real-world datasets. Numerical experiments demonstrate that the proposed algorithms outperform benchmark schemes in terms of test accuracy. The impact of battery capacity is also investigated.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we elaborate on the system model. In Section III, we conduct the convergence analysis and formulate the design problem accordingly. In Section IV, we develop an MDP framework and compute its optimal policy. In Section V, we propose an asymptotically optimal policy with low complexity. In Section VI, we develop an SE-DRL algorithm. Simulation results are presented in Section VII, and we conclude the paper in Section VIII.

To solve the learning problem (1) in a distributed manner, the FL system conducts the following three steps iteratively under the coordination of the server:

  • â€¢

    The server schedules a subset of edge devices and broadcasts the global model to them.

  • â€¢

    Each scheduled device computes its local gradient on its own local dataset by using the received learning model, and then uploads the local gradient to the server.

  • â€¢

    The server aggregates local gradients of scheduled devices and then updates the global model.

Each iteration consisting of these three steps is called a time slot, indexed by tğ‘¡t. The whole training process continues until reaching a preset maxmimum number of time slots Tğ‘‡T.

II-C Communication Model

After local computation, the scheduled edge devices send their local gradients to the server for global aggregation. For the uplink transmission, we adopt an orthogonal frequency division multiple access (OFDMA) technique, where each device occupies one resource block to upload its local gradient. We consider a non-trivial scenario where no more than R<Nğ‘…ğ‘R<N devices can upload their local gradients at one time slot due to the limited bandwidth constraint. Thus, we have

âˆ‘n=1NÎ²n,tâ‰¤R,âˆ€t.superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘subscriptğ›½ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘…for-allğ‘¡\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}\beta_{n,t}\leq R,\forall t. (5)

We assume that the uplink channel is block fading, i.e., the channel fading keeps constant during one time slot. Denote h~n,tsubscript~â„ğ‘›ğ‘¡\tilde{h}_{n,t} as the uplink channel from device nğ‘›n to the server at time slot tğ‘¡t with its channel gain hn,t=|h~n,t|subscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscript~â„ğ‘›ğ‘¡h_{n,t}=|\tilde{h}_{n,t}|. The uplink rate of device nğ‘›n at time slot tğ‘¡t is given by

II-D Energy Harvesting and Update Model

The limited battery capacity of edge devices poses significant challenges in sustaining the long-term operation of the wireless FL system without battery recharging. To address this issue, we consider that each edge device is equipped with an EH device to extract energy from the ambient environment. Furthermore, we assume that each device nğ‘›n is equipped with a rechargeable battery with limited capacity bmaxsuperscriptğ‘b^{\max}. The energy harvested at time slot tğ‘¡t is first stored in the battery and then available at the next time slot t+1ğ‘¡1t+1. Let un,tsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘¡u_{n,t} and bn,tsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡b_{n,t} denote the harvested energy and the energy level of device nğ‘›n at time slot tğ‘¡t, respectively. The energy level dynamics of device nğ‘›n over two adjacent time slots is given by

bn,t+1=minâ¡{bn,t+un,tâˆ’en,t,bmax}.subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘\displaystyle b_{n,t+1}=\min\{b_{n,t}+u_{n,t}-e_{n,t},b^{\max}\}. (12)

The energy consumption at each time slot cannot exceed the current remaining energy in the battery. Thus, the energy causality constraint is given by

III Convergence Analysis and Problem Formulation

In this section, we first present convergence analysis for wireless FL with EH devices, deriving an upper bound for the optimality gap between the expected and optimal global loss. Then, we formulate a joint device scheduling and power control problem to minimize the expected optimality gap.

III-A Convergence Analysis

To facilitate the convergence analysis, we make the following standard assumptions, which are widely adopted in the literature on FL [8, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27].

Assumption 1.

(Smoothness) The local loss function Fnâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ°F_{n}(\boldsymbol{w}) is Lğ¿L-smooth. For any ğš,ğ›âˆˆâ„dğšğ›superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\boldsymbol{a},\boldsymbol{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, nâˆˆ[N]ğ‘›delimited-[]ğ‘n\in[N], we have

Fnâ€‹(ğ’‚)âˆ’Fnâ€‹(ğ’ƒ)â‰¤âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ’ƒ)ğ–³â€‹(ğ’‚âˆ’ğ’ƒ)+L2â€‹â€–ğ’‚âˆ’ğ’ƒâ€–2.subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ’‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ’ƒâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›superscriptğ’ƒğ–³ğ’‚ğ’ƒğ¿2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ’‚ğ’ƒ2\displaystyle\begin{split}F_{n}(\boldsymbol{a})-F_{n}(\boldsymbol{b})\leq\nabla F_{n}(\boldsymbol{b})^{\mathsf{T}}(\boldsymbol{a}-\boldsymbol{b})+\frac{L}{2}\|\boldsymbol{a}-\boldsymbol{b}\|^{2}.\end{split} (14)
Assumption 2.

(Strong Convexity) The local loss function Fnâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ°F_{n}(\boldsymbol{w}) is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex. For any ğš,ğ›âˆˆâ„dğšğ›superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\boldsymbol{a},\boldsymbol{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, nâˆˆ[N]ğ‘›delimited-[]ğ‘n\in[N], we have

Fnâ€‹(ğ’‚)âˆ’Fnâ€‹(ğ’ƒ)â‰¥âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ’ƒ)ğ–³â€‹(ğ’‚âˆ’ğ’ƒ)+Î¼2â€‹â€–ğ’‚âˆ’ğ’ƒâ€–2.subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ’‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ’ƒâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›superscriptğ’ƒğ–³ğ’‚ğ’ƒğœ‡2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ’‚ğ’ƒ2\displaystyle\begin{split}F_{n}(\boldsymbol{a})-F_{n}(\boldsymbol{b})\geq\nabla F_{n}(\boldsymbol{b})^{\mathsf{T}}(\boldsymbol{a}-\boldsymbol{b})+\frac{\mu}{2}\|\boldsymbol{a}-\boldsymbol{b}\|^{2}.\end{split} (15)
Assumption 3.

(Bounded Gradient) For any model ğ°ğ°\boldsymbol{w} and data sample (ğ±n,i,yn,i)subscriptğ±ğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘–(\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i}), there exists a constant Ï>0ğœŒ0\rho>0 satisfying

â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ’˜;ğ’™n,i,yn,i)â€–2â‰¤Ï.superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’˜subscriptğ’™ğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘–2ğœŒ\displaystyle\left\|\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i})\right\|^{2}\leq\rho. (16)

Based on the assumptions above, we characterize the upper bound of the expected optimality gap in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Proof.

Remark 1.

The first term on the right-hand-side (RHS) of (17) denotes the initial error caused by the gap between the initial model ğ°1subscriptğ°1\boldsymbol{w}_{1} and the optimal model ğ°âˆ—superscriptğ°\boldsymbol{w}^{*}, while the second term corresponds to the error caused by partial device participation and packet drops. Specifically, the convergence rate of wireless FL can be improved by scheduling more devices and increasing their transmission power. However, in practical scenarios, both device scheduling and transmission power are constrained by the battery energy level. Thus, the transmission policy should be carefully designed to utilize the limited and uncertain harvested energy effectively.

III-B Problem Formulation

In this paper, we aim to optimize the device scheduling strategy {Î²n,t}subscriptğ›½ğ‘›ğ‘¡\{\beta_{n,t}\} and power control strategy {pn,t}subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡\{p_{n,t}\} to minimize the global loss Fâ€‹(ğ’˜T+1)ğ¹subscriptğ’˜ğ‘‡1F(\boldsymbol{w}_{T+1}) after Tğ‘‡T time slots. However, directly solving this problem is challenging since the global loss is hard to express in a closed form in terms of the transmission strategy. To address this issue, we approximate the actual global loss with its convergence bound derived in Theorem 1, and formulate an optimality gap minimization problem. Moreover, we ignore the first term on the RHS of (17) since it only relates to the initial error and converges to zero as Tğ‘‡T increases. The formulated problem is given by

where ğœ·t={Î²1,t,â€¦,Î²N,t}subscriptğœ·ğ‘¡subscriptğ›½1ğ‘¡â€¦subscriptğ›½ğ‘ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\beta}_{t}=\{\beta_{1,t},\ldots,\beta_{N,t}\} and ğ’‘t={p1,t,â€¦,pN,t}subscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘1ğ‘¡â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{p}_{t}=\{p_{1,t},\ldots,p_{N,t}\}. Constraint C1 corresponds to the bandwidth constraint, while constraint C2 is the energy causality constraint. We remark that instead of adopting heuristic performance metrics (e.g., energy consumption and the number of scheduled devices), we provide a more reasonable objective function based on the convergence bound derived in Theorem 1.

We can further simplify problem (III-B) by substituting the device scheduling indicator Î²n,tsubscriptğ›½ğ‘›ğ‘¡\beta_{n,t} with the transmission power pn,tsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡p_{n,t}. The device nğ‘›n is scheduled only when its transmit power pn,tsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡p_{n,t} is positive, i.e., Î²n,t=ğŸ™{pn,t>0}subscriptğ›½ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscript1subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡0\beta_{n,t}=\mathbbm{1}_{\left\{p_{n,t}>0\right\}}. Thus, problem (III-B) can be simplified as

min{ğ’‘t}t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡1ğ‘‡min\displaystyle\underset{\{\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\}_{t=1}^{T}}{\text{min}} Î·â€‹Ï2â€‹Nâ€‹âˆ‘t=1Tâˆ‘n=1NATâˆ’tâ€‹qn,tâ€‹(hn,t,pn,t)Dnğœ‚ğœŒ2ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptğ´ğ‘‡ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ·ğ‘›\displaystyle~{}\frac{\eta\rho}{2N}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\frac{A^{T-t}q_{n,t}(h_{n,t},p_{n,t})}{D_{n}} (19)
s.t. C2,C2\displaystyle~{}\;\text{C2},
C3:Â â€‹âˆ‘n=1NğŸ™{pn,t>0}â‰¤R,âˆ€t.C3:Â superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘subscript1subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡0ğ‘…for-allğ‘¡\displaystyle~{}\;\text{C3: }\sum_{n=1}^{N}\mathbbm{1}_{\left\{p_{n,t}>0\right\}}\leq R,\forall t.

Constraint C3 is an equivalent transformation of constraint C1.

The reformulated problem (19) falls into the category of stochastic optimization problems, and it is hard to solve due to the inherent uncertainty of channel conditions and harvested energy. We note that the battery energy dynamics naturally exhibit the Markov property, and the first-order Markov chain sufficiently models slow fading channels. Motivated by these observations, we model problem (19) as a finite-horizon MDP and derive its optimal policy in Section IV.

IV MDP Formulation and Optimal Policy

In this section, we first propose an MDP framework for deriving the optimal transmission policy. We prove that the optimal policy can be computed offline using the Bellman equation. Then, we demonstrate that the optimal policy exhibits a monotone structure with respect to the battery and channel states.

IV-A MDP Formulation

To capture the temporal correlation of practical wireless channels, we adopt a finite-state Markov channel model, which has been extensively used to approximate various mathematical and experimental fading models (e.g., indoor channels, Rayleigh fading channels, and Rician fading channels) [28]. The channel is quantified into Nhsubscriptğ‘â„N_{h} states, with its corresponding channel gains quantified by â„‹={H1,H2,â€¦,HNh}â„‹subscriptğ»1subscriptğ»2â€¦subscriptğ»subscriptğ‘â„\mathcal{H}=\left\{H_{1},H_{2},\ldots,H_{N_{h}}\right\}. We note that the objective function in Problem 1 is a weighted sum of costs câ€‹(ğ’‰t,ğ’‘t)ğ‘subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡subscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t}), where the weight ATâˆ’tsuperscriptğ´ğ‘‡ğ‘¡A^{T-t} increases with time slot tğ‘¡t. This formulation differs from the standard discounted MDPs, which apply a discount factor typically less than 111 to diminish the importance of future costs over time. To address this unique inversion of discounting, we introduce a modified Bellman equation in the following subsection to compute the optimal policy for Problem 1.

IV-B Optimal Policy

In this subsection, we show that the optimal policy can be derived offline according to the Bellman equation. Moreover, we prove that the optimal policy possesses a monotone structure with respect to the battery and channel states.

Next, we demonstrate that the optimal policy also exhibits a monotone structure with respect to the channel state. To this end, we first make the following assumption.

Assumption 4.

(The stochastic monotonicity of the channel transition probability matrix) The channel transition probability matrix Î¨nsubscriptÎ¨ğ‘›\Psi_{n}, âˆ€nâˆˆ[N]for-allğ‘›delimited-[]ğ‘\forall n\in[N] is stochastic monotone. For 1â‰¤iâ‰¤iâ€²â‰¤Nh1ğ‘–superscriptğ‘–â€²subscriptğ‘â„1\leq i\leq i^{\prime}\leq N_{h}, 1â‰¤kâ‰¤Nh1ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘â„1\leq k\leq N_{h}, we have

âˆ‘j=kNhÏˆn(iâ€²,j)â‰¥âˆ‘j=kNhÏˆn(i,j).superscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘â„superscriptsubscriptğœ“ğ‘›superscriptğ‘–â€²ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘â„superscriptsubscriptğœ“ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle\begin{split}\sum_{j=k}^{N_{h}}\psi_{n}^{(i^{\prime},j)}\geq\sum_{j=k}^{N_{h}}\psi_{n}^{(i,j)}.\end{split} (34)

Assumption 4 is widely used in the Markov modeling of various fading channels, such as Rayleigh and Rician fading channels [28]. It allows for an intuitive interpretation: better channel quality at the current time slot indicates a higher probability of maintaining better channel quality at the next time slot. Based on Assumption 4, we prove that the optimal policy possesses a monotone structure with respect to the channel state in the following theorem.

Theorem 4.

Given any fixed ğ›tsubscriptğ›ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{b}_{t} and {hm,t,mâˆˆ[N]\n}subscriptâ„ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘š\delimited-[]ğ‘ğ‘›\left\{h_{m,t},m\in[N]\backslash n\right\}, if Assumption 4 holds, the optimal transmission power pn,tâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡p_{n,t}^{*} of device nğ‘›n at time slot tğ‘¡t is non-increasing in its current channel state hn,tsubscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘¡h_{n,t} for 1â‰¤tâ‰¤T1ğ‘¡ğ‘‡1\leq t\leq T.

Proof.

The proof is presented in Appendix D. âˆ

Fig. 2 demonstrates the monotone structure for the optimal policy of one typical device. The benefits for the monotone structure are twofold. First, it reduces the storage space for online implementation, as only the boundary states used for switching transmission power need to be stored. Second, the monotone structure can reduce the computational overhead for solving the Bellman equation. According to the monotone structure, the standard value iteration algorithm can be modified as follows. (35)

We note that equation (36) avoids the brute-force search over the action space ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}, thereby significantly reducing the computational complexity. According to Theorems 3 and 4, the modified algorithm converges to the optimal policy as the standard value iteration algorithm does.

Although the monotone structure can reduce the computational complexity, computing the optimal transmission policy of multiple devices still remains challenging. Specifically, the computational complexity for deriving the optimal policy is ğ’ªâ€‹(|ğ’®|2â€‹|ğ’«|)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ’®2ğ’«\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{S}|^{2}|\mathcal{P}|) [30], where both the state space ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} and the action space ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} grow exponentially with the number of devices Nğ‘N. Thus, the computational complexity also increases exponentially in Nğ‘N. To address the curse of dimensionality, in Section V, we trade off optimality for complexity and develop an asymptotically optimal policy, the computational complexity of which increases only linearly with Nğ‘N.

V Asymptotically Optimal Policy: Relax-and-Truncate Approach

In this section, we first develop a low-complexity algorithm, termed the relax-and-truncate approach, whose computational complexity increases only linearly with the number of devices, Nğ‘N. Then, we prove that the proposed algorithm is asymptotically optimal as Nğ‘N increases.

V-A Device Level Decomposition

We start by observing that Problem 1 is intractable due to constraint C3, which couples the transmission power actions {pn,t,nâˆˆ[N]}subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘›delimited-[]ğ‘\left\{p_{n,t},n\in[N]\right\}, resulting in the exponential complexity. To address this issue, we relax the hard constraint C3 into a time-average constraint. First, we define the time-average number of scheduled devices under a policy Ï€ğœ‹\pi as

Râ€‹(Ï€)=ğ‘…ğœ‹absent\displaystyle R(\pi)= ğ”¼Ï€â€‹[1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t=1Tâˆ‘n=1NğŸ™{pn,t>0}].subscriptğ”¼ğœ‹delimited-[]1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘subscript1subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡0\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\mathbbm{1}_{\left\{p_{n,t}>0\right\}}\right]. (37)

Then, we formulate the relaxed problem as follows.

Problem 2.

(Relaxed Optimality Gap Minimization Problem)

Ï€Â¯âˆ—=argminğœ‹superscriptÂ¯ğœ‹ğœ‹argmin\displaystyle\overline{\pi}^{*}=\underset{\pi}{\textup{argmin}}{}{} Jâ€‹(Ï€)ğ½ğœ‹\displaystyle J(\pi) (38)
s.t. C2,C2\displaystyle\textup{C2},
C3Â¯:Râ€‹(Ï€)â‰¤R.:Â¯C3ğ‘…ğœ‹ğ‘…\displaystyle\overline{\textup{C3}}:R(\pi)\leq R.

The relaxed bandwidth constraint C3Â¯Â¯C3\overline{\textup{C3}} allows more than Rğ‘…R devices to upload local gradients at certain time slots, provided that the time-average bandwidth constraint is satisfied over all time slots. The optimal policy for Problem 2 is referred to as the optimal relaxed policy Ï€Â¯âˆ—superscriptÂ¯ğœ‹\overline{\pi}^{*} hereinafter.

The relaxed constraint C3Â¯Â¯C3\overline{\textup{C3}} in Problem 2 still couples the power actions of all devices. To tackle this issue, we adopt a device level decomposition by using the Lagrange approach [31]. Specifically, we introduce a Lagrange multiplier Î»â‰¥0ğœ†0\lambda\geq 0 and define the Lagrangian associated with Problem 2 as

Thus, the optimal relaxed policy Ï€Â¯âˆ—superscriptÂ¯ğœ‹\overline{\pi}^{*} can be computed by using a two-stage iterative algorithm: 1) For a given Î»ğœ†\lambda, we find the Î»ğœ†\lambda-optimal policy; 2) we update Î»ğœ†\lambda by applying a bisection method. These two steps are detailed in the following.

The decoupled Problem 3 for each device nğ‘›n can be modeled as an MDP and solved by value iteration or policy iteration algorithms.

V-A2 Determination of the Optimal Lagrange Multiplier

According to [32, Lemma 3.1], Râ€‹(Ï€Â¯Î»)ğ‘…subscriptÂ¯ğœ‹ğœ†R(\overline{\pi}_{\lambda}) decreases as Î»ğœ†\lambda increases. Intuitively, the Lagrange multiplier Î»ğœ†\lambda can be interpreted as the cost of scheduling one device; thus, increasing Î»ğœ†\lambda imposes a greater penalty on the scheduling cost in the Lagrangian. Our goal is to identify the smallest value of Î»ğœ†\lambda that satisfies the relaxed bandwidth constraint C3Â¯Â¯C3\overline{\textup{C3}}. Formally, the optimal Lagrange multiplier is defined as

Î»âˆ—=inf{Î»â‰¥0:Râ€‹(Ï€Â¯Î»)â‰¤R}.superscriptğœ†infimumconditional-setğœ†0ğ‘…subscriptÂ¯ğœ‹ğœ†ğ‘…\displaystyle\lambda^{*}=\inf\left\{\lambda\geq 0:R(\overline{\pi}_{\lambda})\leq R\right\}. (43)

To search for the optimal Lagrange multiplier Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*}, we apply the bisection method, which exploits the monotonicity of Râ€‹(Ï€Â¯Î»)ğ‘…subscriptÂ¯ğœ‹ğœ†R(\overline{\pi}_{\lambda}) with respect to Î»ğœ†\lambda. We initialize Î»âˆ’=0superscriptğœ†0\lambda^{-}=0 and Î»+superscriptğœ†\lambda^{+} as a sufficiently large number such that Râ€‹(Ï€Â¯Î»+)<Rğ‘…subscriptÂ¯ğœ‹superscriptğœ†ğ‘…R(\overline{\pi}_{\lambda^{+}})<R. The algorithm terminates when Î»+âˆ’Î»âˆ’<Ïµsuperscriptğœ†superscriptğœ†italic-Ïµ\lambda^{+}-\lambda^{-}<\epsilon, where Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is a sufficiently small constant. We summarize the complete procedure for deriving the optimal relaxed policy Ï€Â¯âˆ—superscriptÂ¯ğœ‹\overline{\pi}^{*} in Algorithm 1.

Remark 2.

By employing the Lagrange approach, solving the relaxed Problem 2 is reduced to solving Nğ‘N subproblems (i.e. Problem 3). It is worth noting that, in this manner, the computational complexity of finding the optimal relaxed policy Ï€Â¯âˆ—superscriptÂ¯ğœ‹\overline{\pi}^{*} increases only linearly with the number of devices Nğ‘N, whereas the computational complexity of computing the optimal policy Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} grows exponentially with Nğ‘N.

V-B Truncation Policy With Hard Bandwidth Constraint

Note that the hard constraint C3 is not guaranteed to be satisfied under the optimal relaxed policy Ï€Â¯âˆ—superscriptÂ¯ğœ‹\overline{\pi}^{*}. To address this issue, we construct a new truncation policy Ï€~~ğœ‹\tilde{\pi} based on Ï€Â¯âˆ—superscriptÂ¯ğœ‹\overline{\pi}^{*} to meet the hard constraint C3. Denote Î©Â¯tsubscriptÂ¯Î©ğ‘¡\overline{\Omega}_{t} as the set of scheduled devices at time slot tğ‘¡t under the optimal relaxed policy Ï€Â¯âˆ—superscriptÂ¯ğœ‹\overline{\pi}^{*}. The truncation policy Ï€~~ğœ‹\tilde{\pi} at each time slot is carried out in two cases as follows:

  • â€¢

    If |Î©Â¯t|â‰¤RsubscriptÂ¯Î©ğ‘¡ğ‘…|\overline{\Omega}_{t}|\leq R, all devices nâˆˆÎ©Â¯tğ‘›subscriptÂ¯Î©ğ‘¡n\in\overline{\Omega}_{t} can upload their local gradients.

  • â€¢

    Otherwise if |Î©Â¯t|>RsubscriptÂ¯Î©ğ‘¡ğ‘…|\overline{\Omega}_{t}|>R, the server schedules a subset of devices Î©~tâŠ†Î©Â¯tsubscript~Î©ğ‘¡subscriptÂ¯Î©ğ‘¡\tilde{\Omega}_{t}\subseteq\overline{\Omega}_{t} randomly such that |Î©~t|=Rsubscript~Î©ğ‘¡ğ‘…|\tilde{\Omega}_{t}|=R. Those devices that are in set Î©Â¯tsubscriptÂ¯Î©ğ‘¡\overline{\Omega}_{t} but not selected in Î©~tsubscript~Î©ğ‘¡\tilde{\Omega}_{t} will not be scheduled to transmit.

V-C Asymptotic Optimality of the Relax-and-Truncate Policy

In this subsection, we analyze the asymptotic optimality of the proposed relax-and-truncate policy. We establish an upper bound for the gap between the expected cumulative costs under the truncation policy Ï€~~ğœ‹\tilde{\pi} and the optimal policy Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} in the following theorem.

Theorem 5.

Assume that the proportion of scheduled devices, Îº=RNğœ…ğ‘…ğ‘\kappa=\frac{R}{N}, remains constant. The gap between the expected cumulative costs under the truncation policy Ï€~~ğœ‹\tilde{\pi} and the optimal policy Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} is upper bounded by

where Dmin=minnâ¡{Dn}subscriptğ·minsubscriptğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›D_{\textup{min}}=\min_{n}\left\{D_{n}\right\}.

Proof.

The proof is presented in Appendix E. âˆ

Remark 3.

According to Theorem 5, when Îº=RNğœ…ğ‘…ğ‘\kappa=\frac{R}{N} is fixed, the cost gap between the proposed relax-and-truncate policy Ï€~~ğœ‹\tilde{\pi} and the optimal policy Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} is ğ’ªâ€‹(1N)ğ’ª1ğ‘\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right). As Nğ‘N increases, the gap approaches zero. Thus, the proposed relax-and-truncate policy is asymptotically optimal for Problem 1 with hard bandwidth constraint.

VI Structure-Enhanced Deep Reinforcement Learning

In this section, we address a more general scenario in which the statistical knowledge of channels and harvested energy is unknown. To this end, we develop a novel structure-enhanced Deep Q-Network (SE-DQN) algorithm that leverages the monotone structure of the optimal policy to improve offline training performance.

VI-A Deep Reinforcement Learning

Solving the MDP formulated in Section IV requires the statistical knowledge of channels and harvested energy. However, this information may be unknown a priori in practice (e.g., edge devices are deployed in unknown or time-varying environments). To address this challenge, the DQN algorithm has been widely adopted [33]. DQN is an extension of the Q-learning algorithm, which uses a state-action value function, known as the Q-function, to estimate the quality of state-action pairs. In the context of the MDP defined in Problem 1, the update rule for the Q-function in Q-learning is given by

Qâ€‹(ğ’‰t,ğ’ƒt,ğ’‘t)ğ‘„subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡subscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡subscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡\displaystyle Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t}) (45)
=\displaystyle= câ€‹(ğ’‰t,ğ’‘t)+Aâˆ’1â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[minğ’‘t+1âˆˆğ’«t+1â¡{Qâ€‹(ğ’‰t+1,ğ’ƒt+1,ğ’‘t+1)}|ğ’‰t,ğ’ƒt,ğ’‘t].ğ‘subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡subscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ´1ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptsubscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡1subscriptğ’«ğ‘¡1ğ‘„subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡1subscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡1subscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡1subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡subscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡subscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡\displaystyle c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t})\!+\!A^{\!-1}\mathbb{E}\!\!\left[\min_{\!\boldsymbol{p}_{t+1}\!\in\mathcal{P}_{t+1}}\!\!\!\left\{\!Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t+1},\boldsymbol{b}_{t+1},\boldsymbol{p}_{t+1})\!\right\}\!\!|\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\right]\!\!.

To effectively handle large state and action spaces, DQN approximates the Q-function using a neural network with parameters ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}, denoted as Qâ€‹(ğ’‰t,ğ’ƒt,ğ’‘t;ğœ½)ğ‘„subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡subscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡subscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡ğœ½Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta}). To train the DQN, a dataset of experiences is first collected by interacting with the environment, with each experience containing the current state, the action taken, the resulting cost, and the next state. Then, the parameters ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta} of DQN are optimized by minimizing the temporal difference (TD) error, which is defined as

TDâ‰œytâˆ’Qâ€‹(ğ’‰t,ğ’ƒt,ğ’‘t;ğœ½),â‰œTDsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘„subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡subscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡subscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡ğœ½\displaystyle\textup{TD}\triangleq y_{t}-Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta}), (46)

where ytsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡y_{t} is the target value defined as

yt=câ€‹(ğ’‰t,ğ’‘t)+Aâˆ’1â€‹minğ’‘t+1âˆˆğ’«t+1â¡Qâ€‹(ğ’‰t+1,ğ’ƒt+1,ğ’‘t+1;ğœ½â€²),subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡subscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ´1subscriptsubscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡1subscriptğ’«ğ‘¡1ğ‘„subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡1subscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡1subscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡1superscriptğœ½â€²\displaystyle y_{t}=c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t})+A^{-1}\min_{\!\!\boldsymbol{p}_{t+1\!}\in\mathcal{P}_{t+1}\!\!}Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t+1},\boldsymbol{b}_{t+1},\boldsymbol{p}_{t+1};\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}), (47)

with ğœ½â€²superscriptğœ½â€²\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime} being the parameters of a target network that stabilizes the training process. By minimizing the TD error, the DQN aligns its estimations with both immediate and future costs, guiding it towards the optimal policy.

VI-B Algorithm Development

The standard DQN algorithm dose not utilize the structural properties of the policy. In this subsection, we develop an SE-DQN algorithm that leverages the monotone structure obtained in Theorems 3 and 4 to improve offline training performance. Specifically, we propose 1) an SE action selection method based on the monotone structure to select reasonable actions; and 2) an SE loss function to penalize actions that do not follow the monotone structure. We present the SE action selection method and the SE loss function in the following.

VI-B1 SE Action Selection

The monotone structure implies that the optimal actions of a state and its adjacent states are related. Thus, we can infer the optimal action for a given state according to the actions taken by adjacent states. At each time slot tğ‘¡t, given the observed state (ğ’‰t,ğ’ƒt)subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡subscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t}), we first compute the actions of its adjacent states as follows:

ğ’‘t+=argâ€‹minğ’‘tâˆˆğ’«tâ¡Qâ€‹(ğ’‰tâˆ’,ğ’ƒt+,ğ’‘t;ğœ½),subscriptsuperscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡subscriptargminsubscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ’«ğ‘¡ğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡subscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡ğœ½\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{p}}^{+}_{t}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}Q(\boldsymbol{h}^{-}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t}^{+},\boldsymbol{p}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta}), (48)
ğ’‘tâˆ’=argâ€‹minğ’‘tâˆˆğ’«tâ¡Qâ€‹(ğ’‰t+,ğ’ƒtâˆ’,ğ’‘t;ğœ½),subscriptsuperscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡subscriptargminsubscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ’«ğ‘¡ğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡subscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡ğœ½\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{p}}^{-}_{t}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}Q(\boldsymbol{h}^{+}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t}^{-},\boldsymbol{p}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta}),

where ğ’‰tâˆ’=ğ’‰tâˆ’ğŸsubscriptsuperscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡1\boldsymbol{h}^{-}_{t}=\boldsymbol{h}_{t}-\boldsymbol{1}, ğ’‰t+=ğ’‰t+ğŸsubscriptsuperscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡1\boldsymbol{h}^{+}_{t}=\boldsymbol{h}_{t}+\boldsymbol{1}, ğ’ƒtâˆ’=ğ’ƒtâˆ’ğŸsubscriptsuperscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡subscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡1\boldsymbol{b}^{-}_{t}=\boldsymbol{b}_{t}-\boldsymbol{1}, ğ’ƒt+=ğ’ƒt+ğŸsubscriptsuperscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡subscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡1\boldsymbol{b}^{+}_{t}=\boldsymbol{b}_{t}+\boldsymbol{1}, and ğŸ1\boldsymbol{1} denotes the all-ones vector. Then, we check whether there exist any actions ğ’‘^tâˆˆğ’«tsubscript^ğ’‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ’«ğ‘¡\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t}\in\mathcal{P}_{t} satisfying

ğ’‘tâˆ’â‰¤ğ’‘^tâ‰¤ğ’‘t+.subscriptsuperscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡subscript^ğ’‘ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{p}}^{-}_{t}\leq\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t}\leq{\boldsymbol{p}}^{+}_{t}. (49)

If such actions ğ’‘^tsubscript^ğ’‘ğ‘¡\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t}, referred to as the SE actions, exist, one of them is randomly selected for execution. Otherwise, if no SE action exists, we execute the greedy action ğ’‘~tsubscript~ğ’‘ğ‘¡\tilde{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t}, which is generated according to the standard DQN algorithm as follows:

ğ’‘~t=argâ€‹minğ’‘tâˆˆğ’«tâ¡Qâ€‹(ğ’‰t,ğ’ƒt,ğ’‘t;ğœ½).subscript~ğ’‘ğ‘¡subscriptargminsubscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ’«ğ‘¡ğ‘„subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡subscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡subscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡ğœ½\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta}). (50)

VI-B2 SE Loss Function

Different from the standard DQN, we develop an action difference (AD) error, which measures the difference between the Q-values of the SE action ğ’‘^tsubscript^ğ’‘ğ‘¡\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t} and the greedy action ğ’‘~tsubscript~ğ’‘ğ‘¡\tilde{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t} as follows:

ADâ‰œQâ€‹(ğ’‰t,ğ’ƒt,ğ’‘^t;ğœ½)âˆ’Qâ€‹(ğ’‰t,ğ’ƒt,ğ’‘~t;ğœ½).â‰œADğ‘„subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡subscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡subscript^ğ’‘ğ‘¡ğœ½ğ‘„subscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡subscriptğ’ƒğ‘¡subscript~ğ’‘ğ‘¡ğœ½\displaystyle\textup{AD}\triangleq Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta})-Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\tilde{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta}). (51)

Since the optimal policy has a monotone structure, the SE action ğ’‘^tsubscript^ğ’‘ğ‘¡\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t} should be close to the greedy action ğ’‘~tsubscript~ğ’‘ğ‘¡\tilde{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t}. Thus, DQN should minimize the AD error. By combining the TD error and AD error, we define the SE loss function as

Lâ€‹(ğœ½)=Î±â€‹TD2+(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹AD2,ğ¿ğœ½ğ›¼superscriptTD21ğ›¼superscriptAD2\displaystyle L(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\alpha\textup{TD}^{2}+(1-\alpha)\textup{AD}^{2}, (52)

where Î±âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in(0,1) is a hyperparameter to balance the importance of the TD error and AD error. To optimize ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}, we minimize the SE loss function Lâ€‹(ğœ½)ğ¿ğœ½L(\boldsymbol{\theta}) by adopting stochastic gradient descent (SGD). The proposed SE-DQN algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 2. In Section VII-C, the performance of the proposed SE-DQN algorithm is evaluated and compared with the standard DQN algorithm.

VII Simulation Results

In this section, we validate the theoretical results and evaluate the performance of the proposed algorithms through numerical experiments on real datasets.

VII-A Simulation Setups

VII-A1 Learning Model Setting

The proposed algorithms are evaluated by implementing the image classification tasks on the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets. For the MNIST dataset, we employ the regularized multinomial logistic regression model, with the loss function defined as follows:

fâ€‹(ğ’˜;ğ’™n,i,yn,i)ğ‘“ğ’˜subscriptğ’™ğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘–\displaystyle f(\boldsymbol{w};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i}) (53)
=\displaystyle= âˆ’âˆ‘c=1CğŸ™{yn,i=c}â€‹logâ¡(expâ¡(ğ’˜cğ–³â€‹ğ’™n,i)âˆ‘j=1Cexpâ¡(ğ’˜jğ–³â€‹ğ’™n,i))+Î±r2â€‹âˆ‘c=1Câ€–ğ’˜câ€–2,superscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ¶subscript1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘ğ–³subscriptğ’™ğ‘›ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ¶superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘—ğ–³subscriptğ’™ğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ¶superscriptnormsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘2\displaystyle\!-\!\sum_{c=1}^{C}\mathbbm{1}_{\!\left\{y_{n,i}=c\right\}}\!\log\!\left(\!\frac{\exp\!\left(\boldsymbol{w}_{c}^{\mathsf{T}}\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i}\right)}{\sum_{j=1}^{C}\exp\!\left(\boldsymbol{w}_{j}^{\mathsf{T}}\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i}\right)}\!\right)\!+\!\frac{\alpha_{r}}{2}\sum_{c=1}^{C}\|\boldsymbol{w}_{c}\|^{2},

where Cğ¶C represents the total number of label categories in the dataset, ğ’˜csubscriptğ’˜ğ‘\boldsymbol{w}_{c} denotes the model parameter vector associated with label category câˆˆ[C]ğ‘delimited-[]ğ¶c\in[C], and Î±r=0.01subscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿ0.01\alpha_{r}=0.01. For the CIFAR-10 dataset, we train a convolutional neural network (CNN) with the following structure: four 3Ã—3333\times 3 convolution layers each with 64 channels and followed by a 2Ã—2222\times 2 max pooling layer, a fully connected layer with 120 units, and finally a 10-unit softmax output layer. Each convolution or fully connected layer is activated by a ReLU function. Both the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets are randomly and uniformly partitioned into Nğ‘N disjoint subsets, and each device holds one subset as its local training dataset. We set the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta as 0.01 for the MNIST dataset and 0.05 for the CIFAR-10 dataset.

VII-A2 Communication Model Setting

The wireless channels from edge devices to the server follow Rayleigh fading and can be modeled as finite-state Markov channels [34]. It is assumed that the current channel state either remains constant or transitions to adjacent states in the next time slot, which is suitable for slow fading channels. The channel transition probability from state Hisubscriptğ»ğ‘–H_{i} to state Hjsubscriptğ»ğ‘—H_{j} can be approximated as follows [28]:

For the energy harvesting model, we employ a realistic data record of the irradiance (i.e., the intensity of the solar radiation in units Î¼ğœ‡\muW/cm2superscriptcm2\text{cm}^{2}) for the month of June from 2008 to 2010, measured at a solar site in Elizabeth City State University [35]. Since edge devices are small, the solar panel area is set as 1 cm2superscriptcm2\text{cm}^{2}. The energy conversion efficiency is assumed to be 20%percent2020\% and we assume that the battery state is randomly initialized.

VII-B Asymptotically Optimal Performance of the Relax-and-Truncate Policy

In this subsection, we empirically validate the asymptotic optimality of the relax-and-truncate policy, as established in Theorem 5. We conduct a classification task on the MNIST dataset to compare the learning performance of the relax-and-truncate policy with the optimal policy. Fig. 3 demonstrates the test accuracy for the number of devices Nğ‘N ranging from 20 to 200 with a bandwidth of R=0.4â€‹Nğ‘…0.4ğ‘R=0.4N. As observed, the performance gap between these two policies diminishes as Nğ‘N increases, which corroborates our theoretical result.

VII-C Offline Training Performance of the SE-DQN Algorithm

In this subsection, we compare the offline training performance of the proposed SE-DQN algorithm with the standard DQN algorithm. Moreover, to demonstrate the necessity of both SE action selection and SE loss function in the SE-DQN algorithm, we also compare the complete SE-DQN with a variant that disables the SE loss function (i.e., setting Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 in (52)). The neural networks of DQN and SE-DQN have identical hyperparameters, each consisting of two fully connected layers with 256 units. Fig. 4 illustrates the optimality gap (i.e., the objective value of Problem 1) achieved by DQN, SE-DQN, and SE-DQN without the SE loss function. As observed, SE-DQN reduces the optimality gap by 25%percent2525\% compared to the DQN algorithm. Furthermore, disabling the SE loss function doubles the training convergence time of the SE-DQN algorithm. Thus, both SE action selection and SE loss function in the SE-DQN algorithm are essential for guaranteeing its offline training performance.

VII-D Comparison With Benchmark Schemes

In this subsection, we demonstrate the superiority of the proposed algorithms to the following three benchmark schemes.

  • â€¢

    Optimal Benchmark: All devices have sufficient energy and bandwidth to upload local gradients without packet drops. This benchmark achieves the ideal performance by completely ignoring the negative effects of wireless channels. However, it is infeasible in practical wireless systems.

  • â€¢

    Greedy Optimality Gap Minimization: At each time slot tğ‘¡t, the server schedules all devices that have remaining battery energy. If the number of eligible devices exceeds Rğ‘…R, the server selects the Rğ‘…R devices with best channel conditions. Each scheduled device depletes its remaining energy to upload the local gradient.

  • â€¢

    Lyapunov-Based Online Optimization: This benchmark employs Lyapunov optimization framework for online optimization [19]. At each time slot tğ‘¡t, it adopts Gibbs sampling for device scheduling. Then, each scheduled device determines its transmission power by solving the per-time-slot subproblem as follows:

    minpn,tsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡min\displaystyle\underset{p_{n,t}}{\text{min}}{}{} Vâ€‹Î·â€‹Ïâ€‹ATâˆ’tâ€‹qn,tâ€‹(hn,t,pn,t)2â€‹Nâ€‹Dn+Qn,tâ€‹en,tğ‘‰ğœ‚ğœŒsuperscriptğ´ğ‘‡ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡2ğ‘subscriptğ·ğ‘›subscriptğ‘„ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡\displaystyle\frac{V\eta\rho A^{T-t}q_{n,t}(h_{n,t},p_{n,t})}{2ND_{n}}+Q_{n,t}e_{n,t} (55)
    s.t. â€„0â‰¤en,tâ‰¤bn,t,â€„0subscriptğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡\displaystyle\;0\leq e_{n,t}\leq b_{n,t},

    where V>0ğ‘‰0V>0 is a tradeoff hyperparameter, and Qn,tsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘›ğ‘¡Q_{n,t} is the virtual queue of device nğ‘›n. The queuing dynamics of Qn,tsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘›ğ‘¡Q_{n,t} is given by

    Qn,t+1=Qn,t+en,tâˆ’un,t.subscriptğ‘„ğ‘›ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘„ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘¡\displaystyle Q_{n,t+1}=Q_{n,t}+e_{n,t}-u_{n,t}. (56)

In Fig. 5, we compare the learning performance of the proposed algorithms with benchmark schemes on the MNIST dataset. We consider N=200ğ‘200N=200 edge devices with a total bandwidth of R=100ğ‘…100R=100. As observed, the proposed algorithms achieve near-optimal learning performance and outperform other benchmarks. The greedy optimality gap minimization scheme myopically uses up all remaining energy at each time slot, leading to poor performance in subsequent time slots. The Lyapunov-based online optimization scheme does not utilize the statistical knowledge of system dynamics, e.g., the distributions of the channel gains and the amount of harvested energy, resulting in poor long-term performance. In contrast, the proposed algorithms leverage the previously known or learned knowledge of channel and energy dynamics to design the transmission policy from a long-term perspective, thereby improving the learning performance.

Fig. 6 shows a similar comparison on the CIFAR-10 dataset. To demonstrate the wide applicability of the proposed algorithms, we implement CNNs as the classifier model, which does not satisfy Assumptions 1 and 2. Despite this, similar empirical performance trends can be observed and our proposed algorithms still outperform other benchmarks, except for the optimal benchmark scheme.

In Fig. 7, we compare the proposed algorithms with other benchmarks under different battery capacities on the MNIST dataset. As can be observed, our proposed algorithms exhibit considerable performance improvements under different battery capacities. For all schemes, the test accuracy increases with battery capacity, since smaller capacities lead to quicker saturation and potential waste of harvested energy. However, once the battery capacity exceeds 9, the accuracy of other benchmarks plateaus, whereas the proposed algorithms continue to exhibit improvement. This divergence can be attributed to the benchmarksâ€™ neglect of battery capacity limitations in their algorithm design. In contrast, the proposed algorithms leverage increased battery capacity to improve state representation and decision-making flexibility, thereby enhancing the learning performance.

VIII Conclusion

In this paper, we have studied FL with EH devices. We have conducted convergence analysis to demonstrate the influence of transmission policy on the learning performance. Based on the convergence bound, we have formulated a joint device scheduling and power control problem to minimize the optimality gap under energy and bandwidth constraints. We have further modeled this optimization problem as an MDP and demonstrated that its optimal policy possesses a monotone structure. We have also proposed a low-complexity relax-and-truncate algorithm that is asymptotically optimal as the number of devices increases. Moreover, for unknown channels and harvested energy statistics, we have developed an SE-DQN algorithm that leverages the monotone structure of the optimal policy to improve the training performance. Finally, extensive numerical experiments have been presented to validate the theoretical results and the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms.
